Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2007 02:16PM Carol1220 wrote: Congrats Anne, Stef , McGaffey, Sheila on getting done. Melody and Cindy - hang in there - it does go fast believe it or not. I am 10 days past my last treatment and still putting the Aquaphor on at least twice a day. With the Aquaphor, I didn't scab as much as I did when I was just using Calendula cream. I was reluctant to use the Aquaphor in the beginning because it was so much like Vaseline and it didn't come completely off when I showered. I was afraid it would 'cook' more if I didn't get it off so I stopped using it. My Doc finally told me that it wouldn't make a difference. My underarm is still tender but getting better every day. It was so raw and painful for about 4 days after I finished and the skin tore on the last day. I still get the sharp pains, too, inside but nothing that is excruciating. Hope you all had a nice weekend - we have rain now - good night for a book and a glass of wine.
Posts.Title: April '07 Camp Nukemboobies k4katz TrishE23

Posts.Title: OK...I know this is so predictable, but I'm spooked! AlaskaDeb deborye

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2007 12:17PM Carol1220 wrote: Hi Connie, I am not sure whether I am having IMRT or external beam. Just made myself a not to call on Monday - I don't remember what they told me. Try not to be afraid of the treatment. It is helping you to get healthy again. You want to use every tool at your disposal to get rid of this beastly disease. I am very fair too, blue eyes, and lost my blonde locks when I was younger - I get them at the hairdresser now! The staff will recommend creams to put on and if you burn, they will stop for a few days to let you heal. You can do this. I just finished Chemo yesterday and I know this will be a breeze compared to Chemo. You don't want to be in a position to have it come back. There is a lot of support on these boards - you should come her often for accurate information and encouragement. We can all do this together. Carol

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2007 03:46PM Carol1220 wrote: I had # 2 today. Yesterday took a while - making sure the machines were set up correctly. and they double booked me because one person will finish up Wednesday and then it will be my time slot. They were running behind yesterday and one lady walked out because she had to wait 30 minutes. I thought that was crazy - walking out on your radiation treatment? They first two weren't bad at all - they have recommended Calendula cream, it's homeopathic. Glad you all sound well. Carol
Posts.Title: April '07 Camp Nukemboobies k4katz TrishE23

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2007 07:46AM Carol1220 wrote: Hi Ladies, I don't get bloodwork either. Why do they order it for you Bernadette? I have been told that they take x-rays every 5th or 6th treatment. And you see the Doctor every Tuesday for any questions or concerns. Nativemainer - I got the tattoos which are hardly noticeable. I imagine that it is convenient for the techs to have the tattoos in order to align machines etc. But if you don't have them, it would just take them more time to set you up. It's not like they couldn't do treatment but it might require x-rays etc every time you went. Not sure. Maybe they can do you at the end of the day if it takes more time. Kristin - 15 already - I was surprised at how quickly my first week went, must feel good to have 15 under your belt already. Did you notice how everyone in the waiting room talks about cancer like they're talking about the weather? They have all kinds too - brain, lung, breast, you name it. I have met some nice people. Have a great weekend everyone - stay well and use your cream. Carol

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 01:01PM Carol1220 wrote: Hi Naomi, I try to stay away from reading survival stats.  It is frightening and bc is scary enough as it is.  But I know how you feel about it always being in the back of your mind.  My Onc told me at the outset that without treatment my chance of recurrence was 80%.  After treatment, I thought she said it was 50/50.  Because there are so many stats out there, most outdated, I am not going to waste energy on thinking 'what if'. Trying to enjoy each day.  We're a strong bunch, we'll be around for a long time.  BTW, I love the story about your aunt.  I cling to those stories.  Carol

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2008 10:40PM Carol1220 wrote: HI Naomi, I have had persistent back pain too and my onc recommended an mri. I didn't even realize until I left her office that I can't have an mri because of the tissue expanders I have. so she scheduled a CAT scan. Of course as soon as the insurance company ok'd the scan, the pain went away. Now I am debating whether or not to have the scan on Tuesday. I guess it's a little bit of having my head in the sand. I understand where you are coming from with the info we get or don't get from our docs. I have been doing what Wink suggested too - a big 3 ring binder and i ask for the results of every test now. At least I have no surprises. It's amazing to me that there are things in the reports that the Doctors never address. I don't know much about hemangiomas but I am hoping that it's a totally benign occurence. Skye, I am hoping your pain will resolve and thank God there were no mets. I know that hemangiomas can disappear completely on their own. Hoping for the best for you. Carol
